        Actually, from <span class="line"><!---->Actually, from <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<!----></a> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<span class="line"><!----> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report!<!----></span><br><br>From a quick scan, it doesn't look like the extension is really needed here - it just seems to be a convenient way to package it.  It seems like the real crash is all from the TryMe.html.  Tentatively removing extensions label; please re-add it if I'm missing something.<span class="line"><!---->From a quick scan, it doesn't look like the extension is really needed here - it just seems to be a convenient way to package it.  It seems like the real crash is all from the TryMe.html.  Tentatively removing extensions label; please re-add it if I'm missing something.<!----></span><br><br>Over to jbroman@ for portals triage.<span class="line"><!---->Over to jbroman@ for portals triage.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 4:35 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 4:35 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<span class="line"><!---->Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<span class="line"><!---->Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<!----></span><br><br>It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<span class="line"><!---->It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr<>.<span class="line"><!---->I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr&lt;&gt;.<!----></span><br><br>The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<span class="line"><!---->The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Well that's indeed weird. I still hardly believe that ASan is working incorrectly. Perhaps more debugging could shed some light, e.g. printing `target` value before<span class="line"><!---->Well that's indeed weird. I still hardly believe that ASan is working incorrectly. Perhaps more debugging could shed some light, e.g. printing `target` value before<!----></span><br><br>target->host()->input_target_client().set_disconnect_handler(<span class="line"><!---->target-&gt;host()-&gt;input_target_client().set_disconnect_handler(<!----></span><br>      base::OnceClosure());<span class="line"><!---->      base::OnceClosure());<!----></span><br><br>could it be so that this code is executed several times? If `target` was really `nullptr`, then ASan would complain about null-deref rather than UaF.<span class="line"><!---->could it be so that this code is executed several times? If `target` was really `nullptr`, then ASan would complain about null-deref rather than UaF.<!----></span><br><br>Another guess: any chance there is a race condition being involved and `target` value isn't always the same across different attempts to reproduce?<span class="line"><!---->Another guess: any chance there is a race condition being involved and `target` value isn't always the same across different attempts to reproduce?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I'm afraid I'm not able to reproduce this using any of the test cases, even if I revert lfg@'s CL in c#20.<span class="line"><!---->I'm afraid I'm not able to reproduce this using any of the test cases, even if I revert lfg@'s CL in c#20.<!----></span><br><br>I think I agree with lfg@'s comments above about this just being a case of a null dereference. From stepping through the destruction code, I don't see how the `host()` could be outlived.<span class="line"><!---->I think I agree with lfg@'s comments above about this just being a case of a null dereference. From stepping through the destruction code, I don't see how the `host()` could be outlived.<!----></span><br><br>So I'm not really sure how to resolve this. I'll go ahead and mark this fixed.<span class="line"><!---->So I'm not really sure how to resolve this.           Comment 42<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c42">Comment 42<!----></a>

          
        by

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products.         This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<span class="line"><!---->This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<!----></span><br><br>For more details visit <span class="line"><!---->For more details visit <!----></span>https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage"><!---->https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<!----></a> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<span class="line"><!----> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

    <mr-comment headinglevel="2" commenterismember=""></mr-comment>
    <mr-comment-list headinglevel="2"></mr-comment-list>
      
    <mr-issue-details class="main-item"><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-details {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background-color: var(--chops-white);
          padding-bottom: 1em;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          flex-direction: column;
          margin: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
        }
        h3 {
          margin-top: 1em;
        }
        mr-description {
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        mr-edit-issue {
          margin-top: 40px;
        }
      </style>
      <mr-description></mr-description>

            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>

        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }

            width: 100%;

            min-height: 0;

          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {

          }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        </div>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        Description #1 by tmm...@acu.edu (Jun 30, 2020)

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <span class="line"><!---->We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<!----></span><br>* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<span class="line"><!---->* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<span class="line"><!---->1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<!----></span><br>2) Install our extension<span class="line"><!---->2) Install our extension<!----></span><br>3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<span class="line"><!---->3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<!----></span><br>4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<span class="line"><!---->4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<!----></span><br>5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<span class="line"><!---->5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<!----></span><br>* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<span class="line"><!---->* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<!----></span><br><br>FILES<span class="line"><!---->FILES<!----></span><br>ASAN.txt - Asan output<span class="line"><!---->ASAN.txt - Asan output<!----></span><br>extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<span class="line"><!---->extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<!----></span><br>TryMe.html - reproduction case<span class="line"><!---->TryMe.html - reproduction case<!----></span><br><br>NOTE:<span class="line"><!---->NOTE:<!----></span><br>We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<span class="line"><!---->We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<!----></span><br><br>ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<span class="line"><!---->ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<!----></span><br>The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <span class="line"><!---->The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<!----></a> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<span class="line"><!----> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<span class="line"><!---->Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<!----></span><br>Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<span class="line"><!---->Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Actually, from <span class="line"><!---->Actually, from <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<!----></a> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<span class="line"><!----> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<span class="line"><!---->Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

          Comment 12<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

    <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 8:51 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 8:51 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 8:51 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<span class="line"><!---->Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<!----></span><br><br>It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<span class="line"><!---->It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr<>.<span class="line"><!---->I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr&lt;&gt;.<!----></span><br><br>The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<span class="line"><!---->The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The access to host() happens here: <span class="line"><!---->The access to host() happens here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=e62845d45e7391e9aea92f2892eefb7e3e4f8b32<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=e62845d45e7391e9aea92f2892eefb7e3e4f8b32"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=e62845d45e7391e9aea92f2892eefb7e3e4f8b32<!----></a><br><br>This is done through a base::WeakPtr that has already been invalidated. See the fixing CL here: <span class="line"><!---->This is done through a base::WeakPtr that has already been invalidated. See the fixing CL here: <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2283824<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2283824"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2283824<!----></a><br><br>So, either:<span class="line"><!---->So, either:<!----></span><br><br>1. There's a problem with the ASAN instrumentation.<span class="line"><!---->1.         Per #23: From playing around with this last night I typically have three calls into FrameSinkId - with the 2nd one causing the ASAN output linked above. It's super racey and target isn't the same for me across reproduction attempts.         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Issue 1101001: Security: UAF Read in Content process
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1101001: Security: UAF Read in Content process
          </h1>
          
            Reported by
            
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      tmm...@acu.edu<a id="user-link" href="/u/2434899825" title="tmm...@acu.edu"><!---->tmm...@acu.edu<!----></a>
      tmm...@acu.edu<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->tmm...@acu.edu<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>

            on 
      Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 1:46 PM EDT

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <span class="line"><!---->We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<!----></span><br>* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<span class="line"><!---->* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<span class="line"><!---->1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<!----></span><br>2) Install our extension<span class="line"><!---->2) Install our extension<!----></span><br>3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<span class="line"><!---->3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<!----></span><br>4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<span class="line"><!---->4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<!----></span><br>5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<span class="line"><!---->5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<!----></span><br>* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<span class="line"><!---->* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<!----></span><br><br>FILES<span class="line"><!---->FILES<!----></span><br>ASAN.txt - Asan output<span class="line"><!---->ASAN.txt - Asan output<!----></span><br>extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<span class="line"><!---->extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<!----></span><br>TryMe.html - reproduction case<span class="line"><!---->TryMe.html - reproduction case<!----></span><br><br>NOTE:<span class="line"><!---->NOTE:<!----></span><br>We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<span class="line"><!---->We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<!----></span><br><br>ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<span class="line"><!---->ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<!----></span><br>The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <span class="line"><!---->The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<!----></a> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<span class="line"><!----> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<span class="line"><!---->Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<!----></span><br>Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<span class="line"><!---->Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Security_Severity-Low -Security_Impact-Head Security_Severity-Medium Security_Impact-None

        Actually, from <span class="line"><!---->Actually, from <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<!----></a> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<span class="line"><!----> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 4:35 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<span class="line"><!---->Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>
      </div>

        Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<span class="line"><!---->Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<!----></span><br><br>It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<span class="line"><!---->It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr<>.<span class="line"><!---->I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr&lt;&gt;.<!----></span><br><br>The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<span class="line"><!---->The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Per #23: From playing around with this last night I typically have three calls into FrameSinkId - with the 2nd one causing the ASAN output linked above. It's super racey and target isn't the same for me across reproduction attempts. I am not seeing target as a nullptr but given how many times I have to run this to get an ASAN crash it wouldn't surprise me if it reproduces as a null-deref in some instances.<span class="line"><!---->Per #23: From playing around with this last night I typically have three calls into FrameSinkId - with the 2nd one causing the ASAN output linked above.         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products.         Description #1 by tmm...@acu.edu (Jun 30, 2020)

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <span class="line"><!---->We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<!----></span><br>* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<span class="line"><!---->* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<span class="line"><!---->1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<!----></span><br>2) Install our extension<span class="line"><!---->2) Install our extension<!----></span><br>3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<span class="line"><!---->3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<!----></span><br>4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<span class="line"><!---->4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<!----></span><br>5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<span class="line"><!---->5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<!----></span><br>* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<span class="line"><!---->* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<!----></span><br><br>FILES<span class="line"><!---->FILES<!----></span><br>ASAN.txt - Asan output<span class="line"><!---->ASAN.txt - Asan output<!----></span><br>extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<span class="line"><!---->extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<!----></span><br>TryMe.html - reproduction case<span class="line"><!---->TryMe.html - reproduction case<!----></span><br><br>NOTE:<span class="line"><!---->NOTE:<!----></span><br>We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<span class="line"><!---->We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<!----></span><br><br>ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<span class="line"><!---->ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<!----></span><br>The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <span class="line"><!---->The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<!----></a> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<span class="line"><!----> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<span class="line"><!---->Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<!----></span><br>Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<span class="line"><!---->Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Actually, from <span class="line"><!---->Actually, from <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<!----></a> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<span class="line"><!----> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<span class="line"><!---->Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

          Comment 12<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

    <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 8:51 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 8:51 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 8:51 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<span class="line"><!---->Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<!----></span><br><br>It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<span class="line"><!---->It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr<>.<span class="line"><!---->I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr&lt;&gt;.<!----></span><br><br>The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<span class="line"><!---->The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The access to host() happens here: <span class="line"><!---->The access to host() happens here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=e62845d45e7391e9aea92f2892eefb7e3e4f8b32<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=e62845d45e7391e9aea92f2892eefb7e3e4f8b32"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=e62845d45e7391e9aea92f2892eefb7e3e4f8b32<!----></a><br><br>This is done through a base::WeakPtr that has already been invalidated. See the fixing CL here: <span class="line"><!---->This is done through a base::WeakPtr that has already been invalidated. See the fixing CL here: <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2283824<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2283824"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2283824<!----></a><br><br>So, either:<span class="line"><!---->So, either:<!----></span><br><br>1. There's a problem with the ASAN instrumentation.<span class="line"><!---->1.         Per #23: From playing around with this last night I typically have three calls into FrameSinkId - with the 2nd one causing the ASAN output linked above. It's super racey and target isn't the same for me across reproduction attempts.         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <span class="line"><!---->We found a UAF while fuzzing chrome with the portals enabled flag on (chrome://flags#enable-portals) <!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 86.0.4187.0 (Developer Build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: 5.3.0-61-generic #55~18.04.1-Ubuntu (Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS x86_64)<!----></span><br>* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<span class="line"><!---->* Note: Did not test on chromiumOS/Windows, I would suspect it works there too<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<span class="line"><!---->1) Enable portals in chrome://flags<!----></span><br>2) Install our extension<span class="line"><!---->2) Install our extension<!----></span><br>3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<span class="line"><!---->3) Run "python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8081" (So that is serves the TryMe.html file for the extension)<!----></span><br>4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<span class="line"><!---->4) Open chrome, click on our extension icon, and select "Crash remote"<!----></span><br>5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<span class="line"><!---->5) You might have to try a few times, but we are currently crashing a majority of the time<!----></span><br>* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<span class="line"><!---->* Note: We appear to sometimes crash outside of the extension process, however I assume that's some sort of weird cache issue we run into (As the stack traces are pretty similar and I've only seen it once or twice)<!----></span><br><br>FILES<span class="line"><!---->FILES<!----></span><br>ASAN.txt - Asan output<span class="line"><!---->ASAN.txt - Asan output<!----></span><br>extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<span class="line"><!---->extension_poc_PortalUAF.zip - our extension to install<!----></span><br>TryMe.html - reproduction case<span class="line"><!---->TryMe.html - reproduction case<!----></span><br><br>NOTE:<span class="line"><!---->NOTE:<!----></span><br>We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<span class="line"><!---->We were told to submit this before completely minimizing the file, and we should have it completely minimized in the next 24hrs or so. That said; the key parts I've identified so far have been noted in the TryMe.html file<!----></span><br><br>ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<span class="line"><!---->ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS:<!----></span><br>The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <span class="line"><!---->The host implementation pointer is freed during the portal being activated while the window is being torn down; however we are still running javascript that references the dangling pointer. We can see here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:content/browser/renderer_host/render_widget_targeter.cc;l=381;drc=0ca01450b41850d09069055f1df5d1eafe6167f6;bpv=1;bpt=1?q=FoundFrameSinkId&amp;originalUrl=https:%2F%2Fcs.chromium.org%2F<!----></a> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<span class="line"><!----> that once host_ is freed, controlling it allows us to immediately dereference the pointer, giving us a way to gain %RIP control<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<span class="line"><!---->Tim Michaud(@TimGMichaud) of Leviathan Security Group and<!----></span><br>Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<span class="line"><!---->Gary Nield (@monobehaviour) of ECSC Group plc<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Actually, from <span class="line"><!---->Actually, from <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/severity-guidelines.md<!----></a> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<span class="line"><!----> it looks like this should be a Medium severity ("Memory corruption that requires a specific extension to be installed"), I'm also changing the impact to None, since portals are enabled by default only on Android, where there are no extensions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

It seems like the real crash is all from the TryMe.html.  Tentatively removing extensions label; please re-add it if I'm missing something.<span class="line"><!---->From a quick scan, it doesn't look like the extension is really needed here - it just seems to be a convenient way to package it.  It seems like the real crash is all from the TryMe.html.  Tentatively removing extensions label; please re-add it if I'm missing something.<!----></span><br><br>Over to jbroman@ for portals triage.<span class="line"><!---->Over to jbroman@ for portals triage.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 5<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      tmm...@acu.edu<a id="user-link" href="/u/2434899825" title="tmm...@acu.edu"><!---->tmm...@acu.edu<!----></a>
      tmm...@acu.edu<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->tmm...@acu.edu<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 4:35 PM EDT
    <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 4:35 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 4:35 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1101001#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 30, 2020, 4:35 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<span class="line"><!---->Any extension that is allowed to open a new tab would be exploitable by this vulnerability, or leveraging a vulnerability in an extension (IE: overwrite the URL used by an extension to open up this malicious webpage / potentially re-using a page opened by an extension [I didn't fully explore this angle]). We've also seen malicious actors buy popular extensions to exploit the user base, and this vulnerability would work for that as well.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        Forgot to add: Extension is here as it made this the most reliable way to crash the process; I left a note in the Reproduction case as to what I was somewhat seeing without, but it wasn't very reliable.<span class="line"><!---->Forgot to add: Extension is here as it made this the most reliable way to crash the process; I left a note in the Reproduction case as to what I was somewhat seeing without, but it wasn't very reliable.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<span class="line"><!---->Got it down to around ~56kb (Attached); there appears to be a timing component that I can't *really* nail down with a smaller reproduction file<!----></span><br><br>It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<span class="line"><!---->It appears to be reliant on racing the setting of the portal's source component, activating the portal, and updating a DOM object. My gut says that as Portal is activated the underlying window (which was opened by the Extension) is freed (Since it's no longer considered an extension's window) as it's redirected to the portal source.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr<>.<span class="line"><!---->I got a fix out for review, but this is not a UaF. This is a nullptr dereference, and the dereference happens on the base::WeakPtr&lt;&gt;.<!----></span><br><br>The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<span class="line"><!---->The ASAN build reports it as a UaF, but the UaF seems to happen on the ASAN instrumentation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users.         This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<span class="line"><!---->This bug has been closed for more than 14 weeks. Removing security view restrictions.<!----></span><br><br>For more details visit <span class="line"><!---->For more details visit <!----></span>https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage"><!---->https://www.chromium.org/issue-tracking/autotriage<!----></a> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<span class="line"><!----> - Your friendly Sheriffbot<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
